Line 87: Line 87:
==== Scale of protests ====
==== Scale of protests ====
Thousands protested in [[Cairo]] on 25 January, with 15,000 alone occupying [[Midan Tahrir|Tahrir Square]];<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|title=Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Jonathan Manthorpe|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution|publisher=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> 200 demonstrators were in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2000 in the eastern city of [[Ismailiya]]; and about 3000 in the northern city of [[Mahallah]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Amir Ahmed|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands protests in Egypt|publisher=CNN|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> These have been the largest demonstrations seen in Egypt since [[1977]] in what were known as the [[1977 Egyptian Bread Riots|Bread Intifada]] or, as [[Anwar El Sadat]] called it, the "Thieves' Intifada". {{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
Thousands protested in [[Cairo]] on 25 January, with 15,000 alone occupying [[Midan Tahrir|Tahrir Square]];<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|title=Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Jonathan Manthorpe|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution|publisher=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> 200 demonstrators were in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2000 in the eastern city of [[Ismailiya]]; and about 3000 in the northern city of [[Mahallah]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Amir Ahmed|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands protests in Egypt|publisher=CNN|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> These have been the largest demonstrations seen in Egypt since [[1977]] in what were known as the [[1977 Egyptian Bread Riots|Bread Intifada]] or, as [[Anwar El Sadat]] called it, the "Thieves' Intifada". {{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
â   â
==== Media censorship ====
  â
[[File:Mubarak Tripping On Tech Generation Media.png|thumb|Political cartoon depicting [[Mubarak]]'s regime being ensnared by technologically-advanced youth protesters]]
  â
Since the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the media outlets inside Egypt and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Sarah Kessler|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|publisher=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> that have helped the protesters spread the news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests have been largely attributed to the involvement of tech savvy youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media. On the 27th of January, it was reported on Twitter by many Egyptian and foreign reporters on the ground that the government has blocked text messaging and [[BlackBerry]] messaging services.<ref name="BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt">{{cite web|author=Leena Rao|url=http://techcrunch.com/2011/01/27/blackberry-internet-service-reportedly-blocked-in-egypt|title=BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt|publisher=[[Techcrunch]]|date=2011-01-27|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> Shortly afterwards, it was reported that all cellphone services were to be suspended on Friday in anticipation of the fourth day of protests, which is expected to be the largest in the country's recent history.{{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
 
=== 26 January ===
=== 26 January ===
Line 146: Line 142:
Officials did not immediately confirm the report that Gamal Mubarak has fled to the British capital with his wife and daughter aboard a private jet.<ref name="Adnkronos"/><ref name="president's son, family flee to Britain">{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Egypt-presidents-son-family-flee-to-Britain/articleshow/7365922.cms|title=Egypt president's son, family flee to Britain|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[The Times of India]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Officials say that Gamal is still in Cairo, but security and government officials themselves do not know exactly where Hosni Mubarak is.<ref name="aljazeera-448"/>
Officials did not immediately confirm the report that Gamal Mubarak has fled to the British capital with his wife and daughter aboard a private jet.<ref name="Adnkronos"/><ref name="president's son, family flee to Britain">{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Egypt-presidents-son-family-flee-to-Britain/articleshow/7365922.cms|title=Egypt president's son, family flee to Britain|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[The Times of India]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Officials say that Gamal is still in Cairo, but security and government officials themselves do not know exactly where Hosni Mubarak is.<ref name="aljazeera-448"/>
â
==== Other domestic ====
+
==== Stock market ====
â
:'''Stock market'''
 
On 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread] [[Bloomberg]]</ref> EGX30 have dropped almost 1000 points since 13 of January 2011. EGX dropped 6.1 percent on Wednesday 26th of Jan. & then another 6.2 percent on Thursday 27th of Jan. before the chief of the Egyptian stock market temporarily suspended trading index on Thursday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE70Q0PT20110127 |title=Egypt Bourse suspends trade after index slides |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate|2011-01-27}}</ref> due to marked losing of points in the first minutes of opening of the session. The Stock index on Thursday decreased by 10.5%.
On 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread] [[Bloomberg]]</ref> EGX30 have dropped almost 1000 points since 13 of January 2011. EGX dropped 6.1 percent on Wednesday 26th of Jan. & then another 6.2 percent on Thursday 27th of Jan. before the chief of the Egyptian stock market temporarily suspended trading index on Thursday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE70Q0PT20110127 |title=Egypt Bourse suspends trade after index slides |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate|2011-01-27}}</ref> due to marked losing of points in the first minutes of opening of the session. The Stock index on Thursday decreased by 10.5%.
â
:'''Internet censorship'''
+
==== Media censorship ====
  +
[[File:Mubarak Tripping On Tech Generation Media.png|thumb|Political cartoon depicting [[Mubarak]]'s regime being ensnared by technologically-advanced youth protesters]]
  +
Since the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the media outlets inside Egypt and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Sarah Kessler|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|publisher=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> that have helped the protesters spread the news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests have been largely attributed to the involvement of tech savvy youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media. On the 27th of January, it was reported on Twitter by many Egyptian and foreign reporters on the ground that the government has blocked text messaging and [[BlackBerry]] messaging services.<ref name="BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt">{{cite web|author=Leena Rao|url=http://techcrunch.com/2011/01/27/blackberry-internet-service-reportedly-blocked-in-egypt|title=BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt|publisher=[[Techcrunch]]|date=2011-01-27|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> Shortly afterwards, it was reported that all cellphone services were to be suspended on Friday in anticipation of the fourth day of protests, which is expected to be the largest in the country's recent history.{{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
  +
[[censorship of Twitter|Twitter]] was sporadically blocked,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/4773.aspx |title=Live updates: Opposition groups protest on Police Day - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=John Ribeiro |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9206459/Twitter_blocked_in_Egypt_after_political_unrest |title=Twitter blocked in Egypt after political unrest |publisher=Computerworld |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=January 25, 2011 by Sarah Kessler View Comments |url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/25/twitter-blocked-in-egypt/ |title=Twitter Blocked in Egypt As Protests Turn Violent |publisher=Mashable.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> then [[censorship of Facebook|Facebook]].<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt_n_814586.html Facebook blocked in Egypt] [[Huffington Post]] 2011/01/26</ref>
[[censorship of Twitter|Twitter]] was sporadically blocked,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/4773.aspx |title=Live updates: Opposition groups protest on Police Day - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=John Ribeiro |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9206459/Twitter_blocked_in_Egypt_after_political_unrest |title=Twitter blocked in Egypt after political unrest |publisher=Computerworld |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=January 25, 2011 by Sarah Kessler View Comments |url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/25/twitter-blocked-in-egypt/ |title=Twitter Blocked in Egypt As Protests Turn Violent |publisher=Mashable.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> then [[censorship of Facebook|Facebook]].<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt_n_814586.html Facebook blocked in Egypt] [[Huffington Post]] 2011/01/26</ref>
